translator_notes: '投鼠忌器' (Chapter 61) is a Chinese idiom meaning 'to be afraid of breaking the vase when throwing at the rat' - hesitating to punish wrongdoers for fear of harming innocent bystanders
'绣春囊' (embroidered spring pouch, Chapter 73) is a euphemism for an erotic object, whose discovery triggers the garden raid
Chapter 74 contains the famous '抄检大观园' (Raiding Grand View Garden) - a turning point in the novel's narrative marking the beginning of the family's decline
'空门' (Empty Gate, Chapter 66) refers to Buddhist monasticism - Liu Xianglian becomes a monk after Third Sister You's suicide
Chapter 62's description of Xiangyun sleeping among peonies is one of the novel's most celebrated visual images
research_notes: Chapters 48-74 cover the middle portion of the 80-chapter text, including key poetry sessions and the You Sisters tragedy
The garden raid (Chapter 74) is considered a critical narrative turning point
